block.p: Girding for talks that could shape a global treaty to avert harmful climate warming, the United States said it cannot meet targets only by cutting back on burning coal and oil, which emit heat-trapping carbon dioxide. It must get credit for the country's forests and fields, which can sop up the same greenhouse gas.

Girding for talks that could shape a global treaty to avert harmful climate warming, the United States said it cannot meet targets only by cutting back on burning coal and oil, which emit heat-trapping carbon dioxide. It must get credit for the country's forests and fields, which can sop up the same greenhouse gas.

Canada, Russia and other countries with lots of green acres are echoing the position. But Europe, largely shorn of forests, says that's cheating, and some environmental groups, eager for more solar panels and fewer power plants, agree.
